text: (cheerful music)
- My name is Alec.

I'm the Vice President of
Network Platform at AWS.

So my role is leading the
network platform organization,
which covers a wide variety of areas.
We're responsible for some services
such as Direct Connect and Route 53.

We're also responsible
for the number of services

and programs that drive the
overall resilience of AWS.

But if I look at what our
organization does as a whole,

you know, the network is
a layer of abstraction

that customers really
shouldn't need to be aware of.
So what I tell our teams

is that our goal is to
make sure that customers

can get to Amazon as quickly
and easily as possible,
and that what we do should just be,
frankly, invisible to our customers.
Well, what drew me to AWS

is just the opportunity to
affect the number of customers

and the scale that is only
possible at a company like that.

I talked with a bunch of
friends who had worked there

and the leadership principles
really resonated with.

I felt it was someplace
that I would enjoy.
Turns out that I have.

The biggest surprise
for me has honestly been

how easy it is for people
to move around Amazon
because of how diverse a business it is.
We really do encourage people

to follow their passions
across the company,

and with a company that
has so many opportunities

from cloud computing
to retail to logistic,
there's just really a very good chance
that you're gonna find something

that it's, really meets up
and aligns with your passions.
I would encourage people

to just find something
that's looks interesting,
but don't be too worried about it.
You know, we talk a lot at Amazon

about one way door decisions
versus two-way door decisions,
and the notion of picking a role in AWS
is very much a two-way door decision,

because you can find something
to work on it for a while

and then decide you might
wanna work on something else,
and we absolutely encourage that.
The network platform organization

is looking for builders
to help us take Amazon
to the next level.

It's common for people
to look at a company
the size of AWS and say,
a lot of the hard problems must be solved,
because, you know, look at how big it is.
But we've only scratched the surface.
We say at Amazon that it's day one,
and we truly believe that.

We've only really just
begun in the journey

and the network platform
organization needs builders
to get us to that next level.

The amount of innovation
that we have in front of us

is way more than what
we've already accomplished.
(cheerful music)
